item.s: Consider if this is right for your child .
this parenting style will work for children that are cooperative and do n't cause much trouble .
on the other hand a child that tends to be quite stubborn and is defiant wo n't benefit from it .

Focus on positive reinforcement . because you wo n't be punishing your child you need to focus on praising and encouraging good behaviours as much as possible . even the small things matter like getting up on time or putting away their toys without being asked .
There is no such thing as praising your child too much , this wo n't spoil them
Make sure to use descriptive praise , instead of saying " good boy " say " i really liked how you did your homework without being asked it really helps me out "

item.s: Reward your child for good behaviours .
Every so often , give your child a reward such as a small new toy or a trip to the pool for good behaviour .
Make sure to explain why they are getting the reward , for example " I thought we could go to the movies tonight because of how nice you were to your brother all week " .

item.s: Ignore bad behaviours .
If your child misbehaves , do not give them the attention they are acting out for until they stop .
Afterwards say something short and quick such as " Thank you for stopping " , then change the subject to something else so you can get on with the day .
You ca n't ignore behaviours like violence and bullying you have will have to intervene
Scold worse behaviours .
It 's important to criticise the behaviour , not the child , so instead of saying " bad girl " , say " I do n't like your behaviour , please stop " .
Keep in mind that this is n't exactly punishing them , it is just asking them to stop their bad behaviour .
Punishing would be grounding them or taking away their screen time .
Make sure your home is judgement-free and listens to everyone 's opinion ; this includes your child 's opinion .
Never judge your child for their behaviour and always listen to their opinion .
They deserve a say in how things work .
This does n't mean they get to dictate everything , but they have an influence on the final decision .
For example , if a the child wants to go to the park but the mum does n't want to drive there then they could settle on a park that is closer to their home .
Make sure to support your child and ask what 's wrong when they feel down .
If you notice a change in their behaviour this could be due to something else that 's happening in their life .
Ask how school was everyday ( to make sure nothing bad happened ) and let your child know they can always come and talk to you .
Be warned that if you judge your child 's actions , even if they were wrong , your child can shut down and stop talking to you .
Sometimes just asking your child politely to do something instead of commanding them to will make them more willing to do it .
Consider hiring a counsellor if your child 's behaviour or emotions get too out of hand .
A child that feels loved and listened to will be more likely to cooperate and have good behavior .
Encourage your child to do things to help around the house - but do n't force them .
If they do help , reward them .

Let children learn from their actions , for example if they do n't wash their uniform before school they will have to wear a dirty uniform to school , or if they stay up late they will be tired the next morning .
Never ever hit a child - this is physical abuse and will severely affect your child , especially if you hit them often .
Do n't say mean things to your child or make fun of them .
It can lower their self esteem and can be considered emotional and verbal abuse .
